rwheeler1022: I saw mine a few weeks ago, before having precancerous cells removed. The doctor (@plannedparenthood_stl_swmo, which has been under Fire because of Missouri’s new archaic abortion laws) gave me the option of seeing it magnified during the pre-op colposcopy. He pointed out what was healthy, and what was being removed. It was fascinating, and made the actual surgery so much less frightening. And he got all the bad cells! Yay for @plannedparenthood’s early and thorough cervical cancer screenings, and their willingness to to educate patients while treating them!

evyan.whitney: HOW TO DO A SELF-EXAM AND SEE YOUR CERVIX— . get a speculum (@babeland_toys sells these!) and spend a few minutes getting familiar with how to use it—i.e., how to adjust it, how to hold it in your hands, how to click it into place, etc. when you’re ready for your self-exam, collect your speculum as well as a handheld mirror, a flashlight, hand sanitizer, a hand towel, and your lube of choice (coconut oil works great if you’re not sensitive to it). . find a comfortable seated position (best arrangement would be sitting on your bed with a bunch of pillows propped up behind you, but do whatever works for you) and do some deep, mindful breathing to relax your body/vagina. lube up the speculum and whenever you’re ready, insert it slowly and gently into your vagina with the handle pointing sideways. if it hurts, stop, take it out and reinsert it with the handle pointing upwards. if it’s helpful, lube up a finger and use it to guide the speculum in. . once the speculum is in, open the speculum (this is where that towel will be handy if your hands are slippery from the lube). keep breathing deeply and mindfully. grab your flashlight and mirror and position it between your legs. shine the flashlight on the opening of your vagina and see what you see. if you’re looking for the cervix, it’ll resemble a fat little donut with a tiny hole in the center. don’t worry if you don’t see it still, just reposition the speculum and/or shift the light source and mirror around. if you still can’t see it, wait a few days and try again as the position of the cervix shifts based on your cycle. after you’ve had a good look, gently take out the speculum and clean yourself up. . if you’d like to feel your cervix, apply some hand sanitizer to your hands and get in a squatted position. put some lube on your fingers and insert one into your vagina. breathe deeply. bare down a bit (like you’re trying to take a poo) and gently start feeling around. you’ll know you’ve hit the cervix if you touch something that feels soft and squishy, like the tip of your nose. if you’re not able to feel it, try again in a few days. . happy spelunking!
